This corridor housed the central archives, the main storeroom and, finally, the rooms reserved for doctors and residents. “The patient is on the 6th floor. It’s not worth taking the lift,” he said, realising his colleague’s intention. “By the time we get there and wait for it to come, it’ll have taken longer than walking down two floors.” The man carrying the case went to enter the corridor, but the other caught his arm.

6 Since his other foot was already raised he couldn’t stay upright. The case rolled down the stairs whilst the man managed to hold on and recover his balance. The two men held their breath as they watched in horror how the case spun over on every step, making a noise that sounded like a bunch of loose keys being shaken in a bag.    His foot slipped the moment he placed it on the first step, twisting his ankle. Without thinking, to stop himself from falling he reached out to grab hold of the bannister with his other hand, letting go of the case.

7 The other nodded, pulling back his hand. “You stay here watching it, in case anyone comes.” He walked quickly through the complex network of corridors until reaching the reception desk in the transplant department, from where the medical team was alerted. The man who seconds before had been in charge of the case reached out his arm to pick it up again. Three seconds later the two men were kneeling down beside it, looking at each other. It’s best to call the doctors.” Without wasting any time he set off down the stairs, taking care not to slip as well. “Don’t!” warned his colleague, “We don’t know if it’s been damaged. “I’ll go,” continued the first.   Finally, the case reached the bottom and stopped. He went down the two floors and went through the door into the hospital.

8  Meanwhile, keeping a firm hold on the bannister, his colleague hadn’t moved. However, the doctors were soon there. Despite the pain, he had no intention of moving, overwhelmed by the superstition that the condition of that liver in some way depended on the suffering he was capable of offering in exchange. He heard them rushing up the service stairwell. Standing beside the case, he was trying to think of anything except the possibility that the content of the package had been damaged by the fall. Directly, three doctors appeared, followed by his colleague. His ankle hurt, he was bearing his weight on his injured foot, whilst the other was hardly touching the step. “Move away, please,” asked one of the doctors, who was kneeling down next to the case.

9 After a brief look the doctor turned to those watching, shaking his head. It divided in two, the outer case opening to reveal a sort of small padded fridge. The fridge had ruptured with the impact, and there was a long split down one side from which a thin stream of refrigerated air was slowly escaping.    He closed the case. He heard a click when the doctor pressed either end of the handle with his thumbs.

10 The superficial condition of the organ appeared to be correct. His gloved hands guided a small syringe, the point located approximately halfway down the left lobe of the liver. With his face covered by a mask, everyone else in the laboratory moved back to give the surgeon in charge space to work.   According to the initial diagnosis, the interior polyurethane bag was urgently transferred to the hepatology laboratory, where the liver was removed for examination. If he was one millimetre out he would damage the organ irreparably. The enzyme activity was still sufficiently low, which gave the medical team hope. He felt decidedly nervous. He had carried out numerous biopsies but never before had a child’s life been hanging in the balance. To check this it was necessary to make a clean puncture and carry out a subsequent biopsy. Everything depended on the metabolic rate.

11 After an interminable half a minute, he moved away from the microscope and looked with concern at his colleagues, who were anxiously awaiting the diagnosis.   Holding his breath, he inserted the needle one centimetre. Relieved to not encounter any resistance, he carefully drew out the plunger. Satisfied, he wiped the sweat from his brow with his uniform and watched as his colleague put barely two drops of liquid on a Petri dish and placed it under the microscope. One quarter of the syringe filled with a transparent liquid, which he passed to one of his colleagues. As he analysed the sample, he sporadically pursed his lips, occasionally lifting his head to blink several times. The surgeon lowered his mask and looked down the tube. The metabolic rate confirmed his worst fears: the organ had definitively deteriorated as a result of the impact.
12  Finally, at 21:26, the medical team certified the death of Robert Bent, without having been able to carry out the liver transplant due to the damage that the organ sustained in transit
